title: Fred de Jong
text:
Fred de Jong (born 5 April 1964) is a New Zealand former <a href="association%20football">football</a> <a href="Striker%20%28association%20football%29">striker</a> who represented <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20soccer%20team">his country</a> in the 1980s and early 1990s.
Club career.
He played senior football with <a href="Mt%20Wellington%20%28Soccer%29">Mt. Wellington</a> before moving to Australia, helping <a href="Marconi%20Stallions">Marconi Stallions</a> to consecutive <a href="National%20Soccer%20League%20%28Australia%29">National Soccer League</a> titles in 1988 and 1989. De Jong then took advantage of his heritage, joining <a href="Fortuna%20Sittard">Fortuna Sittard</a> in the Dutch <a href="Eredivisie">Eredivisie</a> (First Division) in 1990, playing against the likes of <a href="Romario">Romario</a> and <a href="Dennis%20Bergkamp">Dennis Bergkamp</a>. De Jong played three seasons in the Dutch top flight (53 games; 6 goals) and one more in the <a href="Eerste%20Divisie">Eerste Divisie</a> (Second Division). He returned to New Zealand after the Dutch 1993–94 season to play domestically for <a href="Central%20United">Central United</a> and later played in the Australian <a href="National%20Soccer%20League%20%28Australia%29">National Soccer League</a> for the <a href="Football%20Kingz">Football Kingz</a> 1999–2000.
International career.
De Jong marked his <a href="All%20Whites">All Whites</a> debut with a substitute appearance in a 6–1 win over <a href="Malaysia%20national%20football%20team">Malaysia</a> on 3 April 1984 and ended his international playing career with 21 A-international caps and 3 goals to his credit, his final cap coming in a 0–1 loss to <a href="Australia%20national%20football%20team">Australia</a> on 30 May 1993.
Post playing career.
De Jong retains involvement in football serving as a director on the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Football">New Zealand Football</a> board and as vice president of the <a href="Oceania%20Football%20Confederation">Oceania Football Confederation</a>.
He is an occasional TV commentator for SKY TV in New Zealand and has been a contributor of football related articles for the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Herald">New Zealand Herald</a>.
Personal life.
His son <a href="Andre%20de%20Jong">Andre de Jong</a>, played for the <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20under-17%20football%20team">New Zealand national under-17 football team</a>, the <a href="2013%20FIFA%20U-17%20World%20Cup">2013 FIFA U-17 World Cup</a> in the <a href="United%20Arab%20Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a>. Andre played in the team, along with <a href="Alex%20Rufer">Alex Rufer</a>, son of <a href="Shane%20Rufer">Shane Rufer</a> and <a href="Matt%20Ridenton">Matt Ridenton</a>, son of former <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20football%20team">New Zealand All White's</a> player <a href="Michael%20Ridenton">Michael Ridenton</a>.
References.
He is now involved at Ellerslie AFC,where he coaches the 13th grade metro team which his son plays for
